Award.AwardTitle: IRES: U.S.-European International Research Experience-Particle Astrophysics for Undergraduates
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over three summers, this International Research Experience for Students (IRES) effort, led by the University of Wisconsin-River Falls, will provide a total of 18 ten-week research experiences for U.S. undergraduates in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields at partner universities in Belgium, Sweden, and Germany. The European host universities are members of the IceCube Collaboration, which consists of 42 institutions and organizations that work together on the scientific aspects of the IceCube Neutrino Observatory located in Antarctica the South Pole. This observatory is a cubic kilometer of instrumented ice between 1450 and 2450 meters below the surface of the ice sheet. Together, students' guided research experiences will contribute to the broader study of particle astrophysics. At the same time, each participant will gain a beneficial professional introduction to leveraged, large scale, virtual and direct international cooperative research and instrumentation.

The U.S. students selected by the University of Wisconsin-River Falls to participate in this IRES will have access to significant European experimental and theoretical expertise and be able to utilize hardware and software resources located at designated IceCube Collaboration member universities in Brussels, Stockholm, Bonn or Bochum. Prior to research abroad, students first participate in a science and software boot camp at the University of Wisconsin-Madison to ensure appropriate knowledge of IceCube Neutrino Observatory topics and data protocols. Identified topics for further exploration at the European labs include multimessenger astronomy, high-energy cosmic-ray composition and energy spectrum, neutrino oscillations, cosmic-ray anisotropy, point source searches, and indirect searches for dark matter, among others. For broader impact, targeted recruiting efforts and existing institutional networks will ensure that at least one third of the students (six) come from two-year colleges or are participants in the well-established McNair program, which prepares low-income, first-generation and/or underrepresented U.S. undergraduate students for success in doctoral STEM programs. Complementing their early career international research experience, participants will receive mentoring on effective public presentations, including understanding and explaining the interdependence of science and technology and how fundamental research results can lead to innovations while opening new avenues of scientific discovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project offered opportunities to see the world while exploring the Universe during intensive international astrophysics research experiences for undergraduate students at leading European institutions in Germany, Belgium, and Sweden.  Students worked on a wide range of projects associated with the IceCube Neutrino Observatory, which was built and is operated by an international collaboration that now includes more than 350 scientists from about 50 institutions in 12 countries.  IceCube is a pioneering project that has developed an entirely new way to explore the Universe by detecting the nearly invisible neutrino.  Capturing neutrinos requires the biggest single science instrument ever built.  A cubic kilometer of ice was instrumented with over 5000 extremely sensitive light sensors starting 1.5 kilometers below the surface at the South Pole.  

A total of 19 students over 4 summers were selected from a wide variety of institutions including two year colleges, a 4 year comprehensive university, and public and private research universities with Ph.D. programs. To ensure maximal impact, the students had prior experience with astrophysics research at one of the US IceCube collaboration institutions.  This enabled students to integrate quickly into their European partner institutions, and make the most of their 10 week summer research experience.  

Students learned about the design, operation, and basic science goals for the IceCube Neutrino Observatory in their previous projects. In Europe, they made significant contributions to IceCube efforts while developing transferrable skills applicable to a wide range of STEM careers.  Students were placed on projects based on their interests, and the needs of the host institution.  The students got experience working with big data sets, designed, produced, tested, or simulated prototype light detectors for next generation astrophysics projects, or tested data analysis software to optimize performance. 

Of equal importance, their summer in Europe provided a hands-on experience that developed skills to function effectively in an international project.  The students participated in the meetings of their local hosts, and weekly virtual meetings with their colleagues at the University of Wisconsin – River Falls.  They prepared short presentations to concisely capture and report their progress.  Multiple weekend excursions provided opportunities to explore in their host cities and beyond.  Their projects were summarized in posters displayed at a subsequent IceCube Collaboration meeting.
